John Tyler Recommends $500,000 Increase in Administrative Costs

April 10th, 2007

The March 8, 2007 Board of Trustee Information Agenda Item 8.2 requests three (3) new administrators.? The recommendation was made by Human Resources.? In the same agenda, the written staff report makes request for two (2) new administrative positions.? The draft minutes for the meeting state a request for five (5) new administrative positions.

The April 12, 2007 Board of Trustee agenda requests "five (5) new administrative positions".

Blog:? So how many does he want?? 2, 3, or 5?

Jon Tyler, appointed as Interim S/P on a 3-2 vote, holds no previous experience as a college president and no previous administrative experience in instruction, student services or business finance.? Jon Tyler recommends an aggressive build up of administration levels at MSJC with the addition of five (5) new administrators.? This recommendation will have a current fiscal budget impact of +$546,000 and a multi-million dollar impact on MSJC over future years.?

The addition of five (5) new administrators at MSJC will have an immediate negative impact upon the districts ability to provide increased faculty, new class sections and instructional classroom equipment to better serve the students within our district.?

Press Enterprise reports Tem Ed Ctr as “Elephant in Ballroom”

April 6th, 2007

Blog:? Thumbs Down to the Press Enterprise

The proposed Temecula Higher Education Center unraveled because the developer, AGK Group, not the City of Temecula, did not perform according to the contract timeline in attaining the financing to build the $80 million dollars complex. Over a three year period, AGK Group was given four extensions by the City of Temecula.?

The City of Temecula is not responsible for the failure of the project.? The City of Temecula contributed? 4.5 million dollars in improvements to the site over three years.? Last week after repeated extensions, the City of Temecula voted 5-0 to terminate a repeatedly modified agreement with the developer.

Does the Press Enterprise believe that contract agreements are to be extended indefinitely and that non performance factors are to be overlooked?? How could they?? Or, does the PE agree with Joan Sparkman that the non performance of the contract was the City’s fault?? Remember, Joan Sparkman said she would "fight this (action of City of Temecula) tooth and nail".

? AGK Group may be the real "elephant in the ballroom".?

http://www.pe.com/localnews/inland/stories/PE_News_Local_S_sstate06.40178d3.html

Trustee Gene Kadow amused at teachers/makes debased statement

April 5th, 2007

http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2007/04/05/news/californian/8_74_244_4_07.txt

"Kadow expressed amusement at the teachers’ intent to establish a PAC, saying he doubted they could raise sufficient capital to mount challenges against him and Sparkman"

Trustee Gene Kadow made the following debased statement:

"We did not want to go through the process of demeaning the president," Kadow said.

Fact:

Under Gene Kadow’s board leadership, the MSJC board did not provide Zacovic with due process under Government Code 54957, Board Policy 2315 and the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act/Closed sessions/Personnel Matters.? However, the employment? contract was subject to all applicable laws of the State and policies of the Board of Trustees.

Blog:

Gene Kadow and board members Joan Sparkman and Gwen Schlange want the public to believe that they somehow protected the president by not providing him due process.? In their haste to dismiss without due process they have demeaned themselves and jeopardized the college leaving it open to an employment lawsuit.

Did they not contact district counsel concerning the laws of due process? Did not one of them think about due process?? ? Or, were all three so headstrong in their intent to injure that they blatantly disregarded state law?

My request for a legal opinion on this matter (March 26, 2007) has not been provided.?

CalSTRS/MSJC Draft Audit Report

April 4th, 2007

CalSTRSBoardWebSiteWebUI/Page/CalSTRSCom.aspx?PageName=PublicBoardAgenda

http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2005/06/22/news/californian/21_45_456_21_05.txt

"The Maas Companies will receive all proceeds of the contract," Dietrich wrote.? "Thus, Dr. Giese’s service as MSJC’s interim president does not appear to violate STRS’retirement incentive restrictions."?

? CalSTRS Agenda/April 4, 2007/Item 2c./#9 on Staff Report

The above contract issue approved by the Board of Trustees in May 2005, triggered an audit with CalSTRS.? That draft audit report is posted today as a consent item on the California Teachers Retirement Board agenda.? At some point in time this audit becomes a public document.? The college district should also receive a copy to review at a board meeting.

Blog:?

Video tapes and BOT minutes of the December 2005 and January 2006 BOT meetings indicate that current Interim S/P Jon Tyler, speaking as VP of? HR at that time, responded to my questions on this matter, by stating that my continued questions are problematic to the district and that the issue is between CalSTRS and Richard Giese.? Further stating it is not the districts business. Why would it not be district business when it was a district contract??

The issue of retirement earnings is certainly between the retired employee and CalSTRS, however it is my understanding that a retired CalSTRS employee working in a creditable service position is subject to an earnings limitation whether that retired employee works directly for the district or through a consultant and thus the school district must report earnings.? Otherwise, how would CalSTRS ever know??

Despite my repeated questions and the presentation of a formal CalSTRS letter I received in January 2006 regarding the earnings limitation, district counsel, administration and board members did no further discovery to question the arrangement.? They all agreed.? Must be "GroupThink".

The contract with Maas Companies cost the district $17,300 per month/ $207,600 per year.?
